The allegations have been serious enough to be handed to the police.  However, the usual resignation argument that a minister cannot do their job properly until they've &ldquocleared their name does not apply. Alex Salmond sits in no parliament, holds no senior position in the party and is merely a sometime television presenter.  Labour's Rhoda Grant called for Mr Salmond to be suspended in order to create &ldquoa safe space for his accusers &ndash the two women who have made complaints. But it's not at all clear what kind of threat he is supposed to present to these women, or how removing Mr Salmond's membership card would make the space they occupy any more safe. The implication that Alex Salmond is some kind of crazed sex criminal, who cannot be allowed to walk free, is appalling. He's been found guilty of no improper conduct whatever.  Of course, the real damage was done by whoever leaked the confidential details of the allegations that he sexually assaulted two women. This vastly increased pressure on the First Minister to suspend Mr Salmond for the duration. He strenuously rejects the allegations and says he's been denied the right to see the evidence. That's assuming there is any concrete evidence.  Police and government agencies tend to work nowadays on the supposed Macpherson Principle that &ldquovictims should always be believed, which is sometimes taken to mean that actual evidence is superfluous. Following a succession of miscarriages of justice, the politan Police has now abandoned this inversion of the presumption of innocence, and changed its guidance to say that accusers should be &ldquolistened to rather than their allegations automatically accepted as fact. But it may be too late for Alex Salmond. In politics, you are now guilty until proven innocent. All the parties have tended to suspend politicians when allegations become public.  Many in the SNP are dismayed that Ms Sturgeon did not, at the very least, give her former mentor some kind of positive character reference last week, and then refuse to comment further. The First Minister placed herself at the forefront of the controversy, declaring that she was &ldquo100% behind the Permanent Secretary, Leslie Evans, whom Mr Salmond's supporters believe has acted as judge and jury. Her remark that the complaints couldn't be &ldquoswept under the carpet sounded damning.  The unalloyed glee among opposition politicians at what they see as the final humiliation of their greatest former foe is matched in the SNP by a kind of existential despair. It is hard to convey just how important Alex Salmond is to the independence movement. Political journalists and Women for Independence may regard the former leader as a hangover from alpha male politics, but for many ordinary nationalists he has hero status, comparable to that of Charles Stewart Parnell, the 19th century Irish Nationalist with whom Salmond used to compare himself. Unfortunately, that career ended with a sex scandal, too, over Parnell's adultery.  Irish nationalists always believed that Parnell was brought down by Establishment dirty tricks. There is an unshakeable conviction among many in the SNP that today's scandal must be,  not the work of M15, then a move by the deep state to silence an influential voice on the eve of a possible announcement of a second independence referendum. Salmond promised in his so-called Morningside Declaration in May to  to front line politics as soon as indyref2 is announced.  But  this is an establishment plot, then the unfortunate reality for Nationalists is that Nicola Sturgeon finds herself at the apex of it. As the new parliamentary term begins she'll come under intense pressure to suspend Mr Salmond from the party, or be accused of favouritism and hypocrisy. But  Alex Salmond were expelled on the eve of the most crucial SNP conference in years, the consequences would be unimaginable. The SNP has not just been rocked by this development it has been traumatised &ndash and it may never be quite the same again.

title: leading-academics-question-scotlands-flagship-free-education-policy
story: A series of leading voices raised concerns about the policy which sees Scottish students attend university without paying tuition fees as their counterparts do in the rest of the UK. There were also concerns raised about the overall level of funding for higher education.  One senior academic, who is part of the executive team of one of the nation&rsquos leading universities, described the policy as a &lsquoprop for the middle classes&rsquo, and added that free university education was a &lsquosacred cow&rsquo in Scottish public le that could not be openly challenged.  :&nbspNew industrial revolution means workers may never retire, warns Mark Carney  They also called for a &lsquonational debate&rsquo on the issue. They added that there was concern about the current system preventing the widening of access to higher education for those from low-income homes due to the limit put on the numbers of Scottish students at university.  The principal of another leading university, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: &ldquoThe current funding model is unsustainable  we are going to get the level of investment we need to compete at the highest levels internationally and make sure we can take as many young Scots into higher education as possible in order to create a skilled population.&rsquo  Free access to university puts an effective cap on the number of Scottish students that the sector can take in order to keep within Scottish government budgetary guidelines. In England and Wales, fees are around &pound9,000 a year.  "Funding is putting us in a dficult position," the university principal said. "There&rsquos been low investment from the Scottish government for over a decade now. It is time to look at a gradual increase in tuition fees for Scottish students - or at least consider it. A national conversation is needed.  "It is dficult to have that conversation without it being politicised, and that dissuades constructive debate. We need to find a &lsquosafe space&rsquo where we can explore the pros and cons.  "Is free education a good thing? Yes,  it is affordable, but no,  it is a challenge to sustain. A new model would mean more staff, more students and a better Scotland. Universities are places of innovation and we need innovation on this issue now."  Peter Mathieson, principal of Edinburgh University, said there was a &lsquorisk of politicising education&rsquo, adding: "When it comes to the debate around tuition fees, my view is:  you want high quality education then it&rsquos got to be paid for as it is expensive. Whether it is paid for by tuition fees, governments or loans, that is a debate we can have in society.  Mathieson said that the &lsquorole of tuition fees versus other means of funding is very personal for me as I was the first member of my family to go to university&rsquo. His father died young and his family did not have a lot of money, he said, adding that  there had been &lsquotuition fees in my day then I think it less likely I would have gone to university&rsquo.  Mathieson said he did not want the fear of debt to deter students from higher education. However, he said: "The idea that we&rsquove got to make sure higher education is attainable - for me that doesn&rsquot immediately translate into an ideological argument over tuition fees.  He went on: &ldquoWhen I was a school leaver my ability to tolerate debt was very limited, the reality for a lot of school leavers now is that  they are going to go to university they need to be able to tolerate debt. I think that&rsquos an issue we can&rsquot hide from.  He added: &rsquoI think university education without realistic estimates of what it costs is counter-productive. The idea that Scotland doesn&rsquot want tuition fees I can live with, as long as there is a recognition that the money has to come from somewhere. What I don&rsquot accept is that education is free, as it is not."  Mathieson said he wanted to see the contribution from the Scottish government increased. "If we want more Scottish students at university and they aren&rsquot going to pay tuition fees then that level of income needs to be increased."  He mooted more sponsorship from industry - including the armed forces. "In own my field, medicine, the armed forces sponsor some students so you can have army-sponsored medical students who then commit to working with the armed forces after graduation."  Jim McDonald, principal of Strathclyde University, said that his institution delivered &lsquosix times the investment from the government back into the Scottish economy&rsquo, adding: &ldquoI am sure the Scottish government understands the value of the higher education sector but  you look internationally there are many of our competitors both in Europe, America and Asia, which are really ramping up investment in higher education as they see it as a key component of growth.  "This means in order to attract and retain the best academic talent and best students from home and abroad, we need to make sure that higher education is properly funded.  Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, principal of Glasgow University, said he supports the current policy by the Scottish government. Muscatelli said tuition fees are a &lsquosocietal choice. "What we see is that in developed countries, some chose to keep education free - like Scotland, Germany and Scandinavia. What you have to do is invest in the cost of higher education, and frankly we are happy with the investment that we are receiving from the public purse to educate home students. He said Scotland, Germany and Sweden all had &ldquogreat universities. I think you have great publicly funded systems around the world that work very well.  Muscatelli, chair of the Russell Group of leading universities and a prominent economist internationally, added: &ldquoOther countries, such as England, have gone another way, but let&rsquos not kid ourselves, you see the debate in England - fees were introduced and now people are saying perhaps some of this should be publicly funded. Society will periodically go through this debate, but as long as universities are properly funded through the public purse I am perfectly happy with the situation.  John Swinney, the deputy First Minister and education secretary, said he &ldquolooked at tuition fees through the lens of values. The values I associate with education is that society should benefit from collective investment in the educational development of our population - that is the moral purpose of education.  He added: &ldquoWhat comes with that is a commitment to make sure that universities are properly and effectively funded, and that is the very firm commitment we have given to our institutions.  On comments that the effective cap on Scottish student numbers limited access to university for poorer students, Swinney said: &ldquoI don&rsquot accept that point. What is important is that we make sure there are no barriers in the way of young people from a range of backgrounds gaining access to university education.  :&nbspThe Mackintosh Building will be rebuilt - Muriel Gray on the Glasgow School of Art's plan to restore the the iconic building  He also reiterated the government&rsquos commitment to the policy, saying: &ldquoWe are absolutely committed to the policy of no tuition fees approach to university for Scottish students and that will remain the commitment of the SNP government.  Mary Senior, the University and College&rsquos Union Scottish official, said Scotland should not go down the same route as England when it came to tuition fees, and added that the effective cap on Scottish students was a &ldquopressure that needed to be addressed.

title: ferries-out-of-commission-as-repair-work-is-underway-on-fleet-including-new-45m-vessel
story: One is the brand new &pound45million flagship vessel MV Glen Sannox that was launched last year and is due to serve the country's busiest ferry route.  The other is the 35 year old MV Isle of Arran and still serves that route despite being well past its normal operational age.  But neither are currently carrying passengers across the Firth of Clyde from Ardrossan to Brodick on the isle of Arran as they are currently undergoing vital repair work in Greenock, although the MV Isle of Arran is due to be back in operation today .  Meanwhile, the route is served by the MV Caledonian Isles which has also had engineering works carried last week, with engineers making repairs during passenger-only crossings to ensure that people could get to and from the island on a drastically reduced timetable.  It comes after Scotland's main ferry operator, Caledonian MacBrayne, has been heavily criticised after a summer of disruption across the network due to breakdowns, with the average age of vessel on a leline route now 22 years.  Ferry passengers are now facing yet more disruption on CalMac's ageing fleet after the two new prototype vessels, the MV Glen Sannox and its sister ship, which cost &pound100 million have been delayed yet again.  The dual fuel flagships were supposed to be with the ferry operator this summer and autumn, but are now expected next summer and spring 2020.  But the MV Glen Sannox now sits on the Clyde without funnels as engineers work on its bulbous bow - nearly a year after being launched by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.  It comes amid concerns that a 10-fold increase in traffic is already causing severe problems for island communities.  Tourism bosses on the Outer Hebrides have already warned the disruption has cost them millions of pounds already this year.  Stornoway businessman Louis Maciver says he could not sustain his business without reliable ferries.  Mr Maciver, co-owner of Techmobile, a tech company in Stornoway, said 98 percent of his deliveries come by ferry.  He said: "We are totally reliant on them. For us it means we can get the latest games at the same time as they are released online. It gives us a chance to compete."  "To say ferries are vital to our business - and every other business here - is an understatement. We need reliable services.  "The mistake they made was ordering one big ferry to carry both freight and vehicles and passengers . They should have gone for two, smaller and quicker ferries which could have also helped ease the disruption in the event of breakdowns etc."  Ironically the four-year-old MV Loch Seaforth &ndash the biggest and newest large ferry in the CalMac fleet &ndash was not supposed to breakdown because three back-up engines aim to keep the ship going on her regular timetable and speed even  one of her two main engines breaks down.  But that did not prevent a major emergency in the Minch last month when the &pound42 million ship lost power when a severe fault hit the engines&rsquo cooling systems.  Marion Macleod, a lecoach and music teacher who lives in Stornoway, warns that she may have to move to the mainland.  She said: "If there was no reliable ferry service I would leave. This summer has been the worst I can remember for disruption. These islands would not exist without ferries - they are our roads. What we need are services we can trust."  So far this year five ships on Clyde and Hebridean services have been out of service.  Islay, Harris and Uist have all hit by disruption, when the Hebridean Isles built in 1985, one of two ferries that normally serve Islay, was withdrawn to work on the Tarbert and Lochmaddy routes.  Newer ships, such as the MV Clansman, which services the outer Hebrides from Oban, were among those out of action.  The knock-on effect of vessels being redeployed proved to be a severe test for the 32 ferries that serve 51 ports on 49 routes.  Between January and the end of July this year, 2,326 out of 79,203 CalMac scheduled sailings were cancelled.  Of these, 327 were for mechanical reasons. Most of the rest were because of bad weather.  Nigel Scott, spokesman for Western Isles Council, said the authority was meeting Scottish Government ministers soon to "take matters forward."  He said: "Obviously we have been expressing concern about the performance over the summer to the Scottish Government."  "There has been undoubtedly disruption to thousands of passengers, businesses and the islands' economy. We rely on the ferries they are literally leline services for us.  "We have argued for a two ferry solution on the Stornoway to Ullapool route - and right from the start. CalMac are not providing best value for money. There's a delay in new ferries which is disappointing and the new online booking system has not happened".  "Given the importance to communities and businesses in the islands these are serious issues which are impacting on the local economy and travelling public. It could be a factor in people moving away".  Vice Convener of Highland Council Allan Henderson has also vented his frustration at the delay to the two new ferries being built on the Clyde.  Writing in this month's local West Word newspaper,he said: "We have to give the Scottish Government credit for trying to get ship building going again in Scotland, but the decision to continue building super liners for island to mainland ferries, coupled with diesel/LNG technology instead of more nimble ferries that could shuttle back and fore and relieve at other ports has backfired.  "Clearly the yard is not up to the task, with &pound97 million now having been spent and a further &pound30 million 'invested' to get two vessels fitted out, and that is long after they were due. Just think how many ships CalMac could have had at their disposal  conventionally powered 60 metre versions of the Coruisk  had been ordered with that money?  "Another problem caused by this delay and extra financing is that the vessel replacement plan has also been set backwards with the contract having to be delivered on ever ageing vessels and absolutely no more vessels in the pipeline.  Last year, CalMac carried five million passengers, 1.5 million cars, 80,000 buses, and one million metres of commercial traffic.  Figures show the number of motorhomes travelling to the Western Isles has risen over the past decade, with nearly 2,000 heading to Harris alone.  The huge rise in tourists follows the introduction of a Scottish Government scheme to make island ferry fares more affordable.  The Road Equivalent Tarf bases fares on the cost of travelling the equivalent distance by road and was introduced to boost remote economies - and worked so well the number of cars on one route is up by more than 80 per cent.  But tourism operators in the Western Isles say they have lost "millions" from ferry disruption throughout the summer.  Outer Hebrides Tourism  said it saw "no end to the critical issues caused by the continued unreliability of ferries to these islands as we end the season as it began - with disruption."  OHT previously costed ferry disruption to the islands' economy at &pound6m.  Ian Fordham, Chair of OHT, said: "Whilst the Scottish Government must now invest in CalMac to improve fleet resilience, they should also recompense our local businesses and invest in rebuilding confidence in the Outer Hebrides as a tourist destination after the negative economic impact of this summer's ferry fiasco! This has hit tourism business not just this summer but its future growth too."  OHT said ministers must address CalMac&rsquos ageing fleet and its inability to move beyond the "kne-edge on which it sits" for service reliability.  Among its other complaints were that two new ferries were delayed "with nothing else in a build pipeline."  Mr Fordham added:"We continue to raise this signicant risk to the sustainability of our tourism businesses.The Outer Hebrides is a stunning place for tourists to visit and enjoy all year around but we want them to be able to get here and home again without disruption.  "There has been a distinct lack of any visible action this summer from Transport Scotland and successive Scottish Government Ministers - as ministerial responsibility for ferries has changed three times in the past six months alone - to address this despite the local economic impact."  He said four new vessels - in addition to the ones under construction - or three plus a fixed link in the Sound of Harris, are required to provide a satisfactory service and room for the local tourism sector to sustain and flourish.  The First Minister has said she is "determined" to improve ferry services to Scotland's island communities in the wake of widespread concern over reliability.  Nicola Sturgeon said "a range of work" was ongoing to ensure that those living and working on islands "have the services they deserve".  She said: "I am aware, as is the entire government about the pressures on the ferry network, we understand the impact that has on people's lives and businesses in our island communities".  Ferguson Marine shipyard, where the Glen Sannox is berthed, were contacted for comment but did not respond.

title: herald-on-sunday-diary-grunts-screams-and-funny-names-it-must-be-the-work-of-the-hand-of-god
story: Watching last weekend&rsquos US Open tennis final, the loud grunts coming from the players as they served and ed the ball sounded like two disgruntled jungle primates preparing to have a square go. However,  you were a mammal vocalisation researcher listening in &ndash yes there are such people! &ndash you would have been able to tell whether the winner was going to be Novak Djokovic or Juan Martin Del Potro and put your money on Novak to beat the bookies&rsquo odds.  We know that grunting can distract an opponent &ndash one Dutch player was once docked a point for counter-grunting &ndash and can also help a player to hit signicantly harder, but predicting the outcome by grunt? Apparently so. Last year three such researchers at the University of Sussex published a paper in the journal Animal Behaviour entitled &ldquoTennis Grunts Communicate Acoustic Cues to Sex and Contest Outcome. The conclusion was that, when winning, players&rsquo grunts are lower pitched and losers pitch higher.  So  you&rsquore a grunt aficionado you&rsquod be able to confound the Ladbrokes algorithm and cash in. The lead researcher, one Jordan Raine, analysed 394 ying grunts from Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic in the 2011 Wimbledon final and built his research from there. Nadal&rsquos grunt apparently reveals &ldquodeterministic chaos, akin to a motorbike erupting, while Djokovic&rsquos ies a lot, but the one constant is something that sounds like a stled sneeze. Raine &ndash where did he get the grant for this? That's what I want to know &ndash also goes to drama schools to clock the sounds budding actors make when they&rsquore told to imagine themselves in a war, or giving birth or falling from a tall building, or perhaps even being in a tennis final?  Raine, an Andy Murray fan, watched our boy in the second round of the US Open against Fernando Verdasco and knew from the first set it wasn&rsquot going to end well because Verdasco&rsquos pitch became lower while Murray just sounded like he was tired and wanted to go home to put his feet up. The denouement became inevitable when Verdasco served and loudly grunted what sounded like &ldquoAu revoir. It was.  SCREAMS AND ARROWS OF OUTRAGEOUS FORTUNE  Still in the strange but true and absolutely irrelevant category, going up to 11 on the Richter scale of sound effects, is the Wilhelm Scream, the most famous and most-used one in movie history, ululating in more than 370 films to date, from Toy Story to Star Wars &ndash where Luke Skywalker shoots a Stormtrooper on the Death Star who falls off the edge &ndash to Lord of the Rings and Reservoir Dogs.  The effect was called Wilhelm after the on-screen name of an actor who gives it out as he is hit by an arrow in the 1953 Western Charge at Feather River. But it was actually created two years earlier in a Raoul Walsh oater, Distant Drums, starring Gary Cooper, where a soldier is dragged underwater by an alligator and as he goes lets out the bellow. It was dubbed-on in post production by the musician and actor Sheb Wooley who was working on the film as a voice extra.  Wooley has never received proper credit for the scream, nor, I doubt, residuals for re-use. And he certainly shouldn&rsquot get any credit for bringing out possibly the worst-ever song in popular music, The Purple People Eater. It was covered by our own teen pop star in a kilt, Leith's own Jackie Dennis, in 1958. And by Judy Garland.  In the trivia of unwanted facts useful only in a pensioners&rsquo pub quiz it also went to Number One in Finland, recorded by British comedian Barry Cryer.  COLD COMFORT  The family-owned clothing company Johnstons of Elgin reports a record year in turnover and profits, and work at its mills in Hawick and Elgin is booming.  A growing liking for cashmere knitwear by customers in warm climates, like Panama and Dubai, is largely responsible, which seems like a bit of a contradiction in terms, not to say climates. But apparently it&rsquos because shoppers frequent air-conditioned malls and  it gets a bit parky they pop into a shop and purchase a fleecy warm jumper.  International sales are up a whopping 30 per cent. The &ldquooutstanding results were reported by the company&rsquos managing director. And could there be a more apt name for him than Simon Cotton?  MAGGIE MAY? SHE CERTAINLY DID  The sex &rsquon&rsquo drugs lestyle schlockumentary about Princess Margaret during the week reminded me of the nickname of one of her many boyfriends. He was known as &ldquoBungalow Bill because, while there was nothing up top, he was exceedingly well furnished below.  It&rsquos not just royalty &ndash sport, too, throws up many wonderful monnikers. There was the Reading football player Fitz Hall who was known as &ldquoOne Size, for obvious reasons. Aston Villa midfielder Gilles de Bilde was &ldquoBob.  The 1990s Spurs midfielder Justin Edinburgh was known as &ldquoMusselburgh because it was just in Edinburgh.  The rugby player Martin Offiah was &ldquoChariots. Of course. The Gloucestershire cricketer Paul Romaines was &ldquoHuman. And when Ewan McGregor's brother was in the RAF his call sign was &ldquoObitwo.  Then there was the diddy police officer called &ldquoLaptop, because he was a small PC. I&rsquoll stop there before I get to Gordon &ldquoJukebox Durie.  NEW ROLE FOR THE HAND OF GOD  On Wednesday last week, the French sports diary L&rsquoEquipe published a rather cruel cartoon about Diego Maradona as the news came out that he&rsquos been appointed manager of a Mexican side.  I&rsquove been rather fond of him since witnessing his first international goal for Argentina against Scotland, of course, at Hampden Park in 1979.  It&rsquos been all downhill since he stopped playing, with ballooning weight. He's also a recovering drug addict.  He also collapsed rather dramatically in a box &ndash not the penalty one &ndash watching Argentina against Nigeria in the World Cup in June. Now, rather strangely, he&rsquos been made boss of Dorados, third bottom of the Mexican second ision. The club is based in Culiac&aacuten, which is the home of the Sinaloa drug cartel. Perhaps he just wanted to cut out the middle men?  MILLAR&rsquoS CROSSING  The professional cycling union, the CPA , is about as democratic as Stalin&rsquos USSR, with Chris Froome calling it a dictatorship, joined by the present Tour de France winner Geraint Thomas firing his own broadside at the establishment.  The presidency is up for the vote in nine days with the incumbent, Gianni Bugno, going for re-election. Under the rules riders can only vote  they turn up to the meeting, which is in Innsbruck, and given the pro racing season is still going strong it&rsquos not very likely that many will.  The sport has often been in the news for all the wrong reasons, or the pre-eminent one, drugs. In one of those gambits you might describe as setting a gamekeeper to catch a thief  step forward the challenger to Bugno, Scotland&rsquos own David Millar.  Millar, when he was a notable competitor, was banned for two years for, er, doping.

title: scotlands-cool-list-continued-from-60-to-21
story: The same rules apply. These are people who either live in Scotland, or are Scots having an impact in other parts of the world.  Their coolness may reside in the way that they look, the things that they make, or the impact they have had in shaping Scotland and the world. They can be gallus folk with attitude, people who have pushed for change, or artists who have create work that has blown our minds.  You may disagree with some of them. You may feel we&rsquove missed key figures &ndash  so, please do get in touch. But bear in mind, there are still 20 more to go.  Who will be the coolest person in Scotland? You&rsquoll find out next week.  60 Jannica Honey  Photographer, 44  Why? Her photographs make us love ours bodies  She has photographed everything from Edinburgh strippers to Orange marches, but her latest, most personal work has been a series of women, shot naked at twilight on the new moon &ndash and they have created a whole body positivity moment. At talks connected to her exhibitions, women are opening up about their bodies and how they feel about them. The Edinburgh-based Swedish photographer is also battling hard against censorship of the female body on social media. Her next project, she speculates, is likely to be on fathers and sons, again naked on the new moon. &ldquoI think, she says, &ldquopeople are just people and people just need to be seen and feel some love sometimes.  59 Keith McIvor  DJ, 50  Why? He&rsquos a DJ legend  As JD Twitch, one half of DJ duo Optimo, Keith McIvor set up the legendary 1990s club night, Pure, and was founder of Optimo Espacio whose weekly residency ran in Glasgow&rsquos the Sub club till 2000. The weekly gigs came to an end, but Optimo kept DJing and touring and became a global phenomenon. In recent years, they&rsquove brought their eclectic and experimental coolness right back to Glasgow, opening the Bananamoon bar on Great Western Road and playing big parties like their 20th birthday bash. He and his Optimo partner, Jonnie Wilkes, are frequently on tour and regularly releasing new music. &ldquoUp next, he says, &ldquois an archive release from Port Glasgow&rsquos finest Robert Rental. In November, McIvor releases a compliation of German post-punk music called Kreaturen Der Nacht. He also once lobbed an egg at Margaret Thatcher. &ldquoIt missed, he says.  58 Tammy Koslowski  Nail entrepreneur, 29  Why? Nail art is huge &ndash and she&rsquos the Glasgow guru  Stay sassy. That&rsquos the slogan on the neon lights and merchandise of Glasgow&rsquos NAF! and  one person knows how to do that it&rsquos the salon&rsquos boss Tammy Koslowski. Not only is she the business-mind behind the salon, which won Nail Salon Of The Year last year, but she has painted nails for major fashion campaigns &ndash most notably Stella McCartney&rsquos Winter 2017. Her salon is reputedly up for trying whatever wild and wacky nail art designs you fancy &ndash and even boasts an in-house pooch, Betty. &ldquoShe&rsquos been my sidekick for eight years, says Koslowski. It was when she was bored, eight years ago, while working on her dissertation for her clothing design and technology course, that she first started painting her nails. &ldquoI got a little nail art pen and started doodling leopard print on my nails and it just totally snowballed from there.  57 Christopher Millington  Model, 28  Why? He is the beard  Back in 2015 a tweet by iconic bearded-model Christopher Millington saying that the beard was &ldquoover caused a wave of panicked news articles. It was as  the oracle had spoken. RIP beard. Of course, it turned out that this was a slight exaggeration. The beard was not over, but massively pared down from the great, flowing fleece it once was to something a little sharper. Indeed, you can still see it now on Instagram posts by the model, who no lives in New York. Sometimes called the Bearded Scotsman, Millington was scouted in the streets of London by Urban Outfitters and has been a feature of fashion campaigns ever since. He now has 485,000 followers on Instagram. We still await the date when Millington goes for the full clean shave. Then we&rsquoll definitely know the beard is dead.  56 Logan Hannah  Motor sports champion, 17  Why? She&rsquos the girl racer who is going to beat the boys  At 16 years old, East Kilbridge teenager Logan Hannah made history by becoming the first woman to compete at the F4UAE races &ndash and she made it clear this was just the start of things. Her ambition is to make it to F1 or American IndyCar and be a role model for girls. &ldquoI hope, she said in a BBC interview earlier this year, &ldquoto get to a certain level that I&rsquom not only viewed as a female driver but as a driver itself&hellip We are just as good as the boys,  not better. Her interest in driving was sparked when, as a youngster, she hung out with her motor-racing father, Graeme Hannah, in his pit garage. &ldquoAs much as she has enjoyed coming to the events, her dad has said, &ldquoshe always said, &lsquoDad, I&rsquod rather be driving.&rsquo  55 Christopher Kane  Fashion designer, 36  Why? He gave us back the joy of sex &ndash on a catwalk  Kane is the biggest Scottish name in fashion and style, worn by the Duchess of Cambridge, Michelle Obama and Cate Blanchett. He&rsquos also daring, and last year, while most creatives, in the wake of #MeToo, were being cautious around anything too sexy, he brought out a collection inspired by the 1970s Joy Of Sex manuals and fizzing with eroticism and suburban kinkiness. &ldquoI have never shied away from sex in the collections and this one is no dferent, said Kane. &ldquoSince the beginning, I have found it fundamental to our idea of women. Women with their own power who create their own worlds. This week sees his new collection hit the catwalk at London Fashion Week. Bring on the joy.  54 Dougie Wallace  Photographer  Why? He shows us the super-rich in their grotesque glory  53 Sorcha Groundsell  Actor, 20  Why? She&rsquos a shapeshter who loves to croft  This summer, it was hard to escape the hype around the new Netflix teen supernatural drama, the Innocents &ndash a show which The Atlantic described as &ldquothe most Netflixy dramatic series ever made.There, in every trailer, advert or article, was the face of its 20-year-old Scottish star, Sorcha Groundsell. Hitherto little-known, the Gaelic-speaking, Lewis-raised actress is now huge, and signed up for six seasons as shapeshter June McDaniel. But what makes her coolest of all is that, in the run up to the series launch, she wasn&rsquot working the international party scene &ndash rather she was hanging out for three weeks on her parents&rsquo Hebridean croft, making hay. &ldquoI think it&rsquos really nice to be able to do something that is so removed from acting, she said. &ldquoIt&rsquos good to be somewhere I can just mooch about in my wellies."  52 Andrew Fleming-Brown  Arts venue founder, 40  Why? He shows us what you can do with a big warehouse  Andrew Fleming-Brown is also known as Mutley, the brains behind one of Scotland&rsquos leading arts and music venues, SWG3. The father-of-two, married to model Lauren Tempany, started his career as a promoter and curator, but when, in 2005, a derelict site in a former Tobacco Bond warehouse became available, he jumped at the chance of taking it on. Thus SWG3 was born. But what exactly is it? It&rsquos a clubbing destination, a caf&eacute, a massive outdoor space called the Yard, a TV studio facility and much, much more. SWG3 regularly host the hippest art events, pop-ups and live gigs. &ldquoWe&rsquore unique, said Fleming-Brown last year. &ldquoThat whole warehouse culture has been booming in London for ten years but we don&rsquot really have anything else like that in Glasgow.  51 Pam Hogg  Designer  Why? All the cool cats have worn her cat suits  Name a female pop or rock icon &ndash Rihanna, Kylie Minogue, Debbie Harry, Lady Gaga &ndash and they&rsquove probably worn Pam Hogg&rsquos clothes. &ldquoEvery woman who&rsquos ever tried on one of my catsuits has said, &lsquoOh my God, I can&rsquot wear that!&rsquo she has said. &ldquoI always tell them to just try it on. When they do, they instantly feel empowered. For Hogg is all about that female power. Her 2014 collection, Courage, was a tribute to the Russian activist collective Pussy Riot.  The post-punk designer started designing back in the early 1980s. Not content with just being a designer, however, Hogg has also done her time on stage as a singer and musician, and even supported Debbie Harry on the Blondie comeback tour. Her latest project has been to design the costumes for the Citizen&rsquos Theatre&rsquos production of Cyrano De Bergerac &ndash and, of course, they rock.  50 Malath Abbas  Games designer, 37  Why? It&rsquos games. Enough said!  Games culture in Scotland is changing. It&rsquos not all about the big studios making Grand Theft Auto and Minecraft. There&rsquos also an alternative scene of people hanging out, playing together and making more personal and experimental games. People like Malath Abbas, founder of the Dundee-based Biome collective in Dundee. Originally from Iraq, Abbas grew up in Liverpool and came to Dundee because of its thriving games industry. He believes games can be about so much more than what you can do with a screen.  &ldquoI&rsquom interested, he says, &ldquoin the idea of taking games away from the screen and seeing the city a landscape as being playful. Biome collaborated on the spectacular sound and light installation at the V&ampA opening party last week. Currently, they are working on a virtual reality game called Garden, in which the player plants neon plants that make music. &ldquoWe&rsquore trying to create a VR experience that&rsquos mindful, relaxing and is actually appealing to a broad spectrum of people, says Abbas.  49 Louise Rusk  Restaurateur, 37  Why? She&rsquos queen of the Tomahawk steak  We all know veganism is cooler than cool. But, actually, so is meat &ndash particularly when it&rsquos grass-fed, hung-on the bone beef, dry-aged for 35 days. And nowhere does that quite like The Butchershop Bar And Grill, set up by Louise and her husband James Rusk, son of hair gurus Irvine and Rita. The former fitness professional, who toured the world as an Irish dancer at just 18 years old, is behind some of Glasgow&rsquos coolest eateries, whether they be The Spanish Butcher or Hutcheson&rsquos Grill, and they are as much about the style and design as the locally sourced food. Her own favourite meal? &ldquoHas to be a Sunday Roast. Grew up with our family coming together every Sunday and we continue the tradition to this day.  48 Scott Reid  Actor, 25  Why? He is one of the best actors of his generation.  Scott Reid burst onto our television screens in BBC Scotland comedy series Still Game playing Methadone Mick, a recovering drug addict with a heart of gold and set of gnashers to rival the toothy grin of former footballer Frank McAvennie . The character, who debuted in 2016, became an instant favourite among viewers. When did Reid, 25, first get an inkling his star was on the rise? Well, there was seeing his face tattooed on a stranger&rsquos leg. And people sharing pictures of themselves dressed up as him at Hallowe&rsquoen. Oh, and a Glasgow bar named a cocktail in his honour. Further testament came when fans snapped up 10,000 sets of replica rubber teeth during the Still Game Live 2 shows at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow last year.  Reid, who hails from Paisley, has since gone on to roles in BBC police drama Line of Duty. He will  to our screens in the final series of Still Game this autumn and recently shot Amazon Prime sci-fi fantasy Carnival Row, which is due out in early 2019.  47 Val McDermid  Author, 63  Why? She remains the undisputed queen of crime  Sell as many books as Val McDermid has &ndash 40 million or so &ndash and you ought to be more establishment than cool. But somehow the Queen of Crime has never quite lost her alternative vibe, and with another novel featuring cold case detective Karen Pirie out last month she&rsquos still firing on all literary cylinders. Meanwhile her plots continue to be highly relevant. Last year&rsquos Insidious Intent, for instance threw a light on coercive control in a year in which the new Scottish domestic abuse law was being passed. &ldquoI don&rsquot do it with any sense of banging the drum, she explained in a recent interview. &ldquoBut I do it because things come along that interest me and I think will interest my readers.  46 Talat Yaqoob  Feminist, 32  Why? She&rsquos the powerhouse bringing equality to the workplace  If you want to know just how cool Talat Yaqoob is the best place to start is the forceful, funny and strident TEDx talk she did on &ldquoreclaiming feminism back in 2014. &ldquoImagine, she said, &ldquo we and every one of us challenged sexism &ndash it would cease to exist. Yaqoob has been fighting that battle ever since, and doing so in ways that are changing the climate in Scotland. She was a founder of Women 50:50, an organisation campaigning for equal representation and is now director of Equate Scotland, an organisation promoting women in STEM.  But Yaqoob didn&rsquot come from a particularly political family. &ldquoInequality isn&rsquot something that we would have talked about in any academic way, it&rsquos just something we lived &ndash constantly. Her parents were immigrants from Pakistan who came to Scotland in the 1950s. &ldquoI&rsquom first generation here she says, &ldquoand being a woman, being a woman of colour, being a Muslim woman - all of those things, all of those experiences, come with the experience of inequality. Once you&rsquove had your eyes opened to that, it&rsquos not something that you can ignore.  45 Oli Norman  Entrepreneur, 42  Why? His Merchant City HQ has a Prosecco bar  One of the hippest things about Oli Norman is not that his itison, luxury deals website has been phenomenally successful, or that he&rsquos married to presenter Cat Cubie &ndash these things are quite cool &not but that his company, last year was named one of the 100 best UK companies to work for. In other words, he&rsquos the man behind Scotland&rsquos coolest office, complete with complementary Prosecco bar, fairy-lit oak tree and yoga studio. &ldquoThe itison office, he says, &ldquois an experiment in breaking down the barriers between work and le.  But Norman also deserves a place on this list because of his support for the homeless. Itison&rsquos fundraising feeds Social Bite&rsquos entire programme over the whole year. We also like his work philosophy. &ldquoI only choose, he says, &ldquoto do things that I&rsquoll find fun  things aren&rsquot fun, we stop doing them. Simple.  44 Moyo Akand&eacute  Actor  Why? She&rsquos making films that tell black stories  When Moyo Akand&eacute, and her sister Morayo, brought out their first film collaboration, 1745 it became one of the most-talked about short films in Scotland in years.  Inspired by real adverts published in 18th century newspapers for runaway slaves, it told the story of two sisters on the run from their Highland master.  But Moyo Akand&eacute is about more than 1745. The daughter of Nigerian immigrants is making an impact in her industry on many levels. Earlier this year, she starred as a kick-ass thief in the disaster-movie, The Hurricane Heist, and this autumn she&rsquos set to appear in The Cry, a television baby-abduction drama starring Jenna Coleman.  What we&rsquore most looking forward to, though, is the Akand&eacute sister&rsquos planned feature version of 1745. &ldquoWe saw, she said to us earlier this year, &ldquothat there weren&rsquot many challenging roles for women of colour in this industry. We put our heads together and thought  there aren&rsquot those roles out there, we might as well create them for ourselves.  43 Kayus Bankole  Musician,30  Why? He&rsquos hip, hot and now  It wasn&rsquot surprising when Young Fathers won the award for Scottish Album Of The Year . Anyone who had heard Cocoa Sugar, by the hip-hop trio, probably saw it coming.  Besides, everything they do makes its mark. Back in 2014 they won the Mercury prize with their album Dead. Six of their songs were in last year&rsquos T2: Trainspotting and defined the movie&rsquos sound. This is also the second time they&rsquove won SAY.  So, they&rsquore indisputably cool &ndash and really it&rsquos hard to say which of the three of them is coolest. Here, we&rsquove picked Kayus Bankole, but it could have been any member of this band that delivers a sound that is like no other. As James Milton wrote in the NME, &ldquo&lsquoCocoa Sugar&rsquo isn&rsquot a filtered version of what came before. Instead, it cements their status as riled-up oddballs determined to reinvent the wheel.  42 Vic Henderson  Chef, 41  Why? The chef&nbspgave vegans the restaurants they deserve  Veganism is cool. But that&rsquos not the only reason why Vic Henderson, the resident chef at The 78 Bar &amp Kitchen, is cool. Henderson, who identies as non-binary, and goes under the pronoun &ldquothey, had always cooked for the whole of their&nbspfamily from an early age.  &ldquoWhen I moved out, says the chef, &ldquoI started cooking a lot when I was away with my bands or when touring bands stayed at my house. It would always be vegan and would always be like a big pot of something delicious.  Right now, Henderson&rsquos plan is to open a fine-dining restaurant in Glasgow. &ldquoI still think there&rsquos a gap in the market for places to go that are next level for vegans and non-vegans alike. It would bring Glasgow up to the same standard as vegan destinations like London, Los Angeles and New York.  Henderson, who also worked up&nbspMono in Glasgow and the Harmonium in Leith, sports some impressive tattoos, one of which is an armoured skeleton. &ldquoI just got that from my friend Paul Clav&eacute. He&rsquos one of my favourite tattooists as he has the best chat when you get tattoos. You end up taking about veganism, toxic masculinity, gender issues, cool nieces or daughters, fat politics, period poverty, music, food and loads of other important stuff. Plus his drawings are badass!  41 Ervin Trykowski  Global whisky ambassador, 31  Why? He gives whisky that  Millennial vibe  Manila, Singapore, Sydney, Melbourne, Bali &hellip the global whisky ambassador for Singleton whisky  seems like he&rsquos been everywhere in the last year, and not just to pour a few drams either.  In Manila he was in a bar juggling spinning vinyl and providing a range of Scottish whisky cocktails. Trykowski who hails from Aberdeen and has a Polish grandfather, is giving whisky a vibe that is young and hip. As Esquire put it, &ldquohe&rsquos the Millennial man fronting the 180-year-old whisky maker.  The former bartender and mixologist, however, is always glad to get back home from his travels to his two French bulldogs, Bont&egrave and Clyde. He also has a quirky obsession with badgers. &ldquoOh, yeah, he says. &ldquoI&rsquove got a big badger tattoo on the back of my arm. Don&rsquot ask why, I can&rsquot remember. I&rsquom a big fan of the Mustelid family. The badgers, pine martens, stoats, weasels. I think they&rsquore cool guys.  40 Clara McGregor  Model and photographer, 22  Why? She&rsquos a rebel who out-cools her famous dad  22 years on from Trainspotting Ewan McGregor is now so huge it&rsquos hard to see him as cool. But his daughter, Clara, now that&rsquos a dferent matter.  The photographer and model is proving to be such a rebel she warrants a place on this list. Last autumn, she caught media attention when, following the break-up of her parents she tweeted that her dad&rsquos new girlfriend was &ldquotrash. In spring, her photos featured in Playboy, along with the headline, &ldquoClara McGregor Isn&rsquot Just Ewan&rsquos Daughter. She&rsquos Your New Crush.  What&rsquos her grand plan? To be an actor, of course. &ldquoHonestly, as she said to Playboy, &ldquoI would love to play someone like Patti Smith&hellip There are so many badass women who would be so cool to play. Lee Miller, who was one of the first female war photographers, is another.  39 Tom Walkinshaw  Space entrepreneur, 28  Why? He&rsquos the man behind the world&rsquos smallest, lightest satellites  Seven years ago Tom Walkinshaw was graduating in business studies at Glasgow Caledonia University, and thinking he might like to get a job in the space industry. Only there wasn&rsquot that much of an industry in Scotland back then, so he decided to help start it. He created Alba Orbital and dedicated himself to developing the cheapest, lightest satellite.  These tiny devices are called picosats, just around a kilogram in weight, and are revolutionary. &ldquoAlba really started to make it viable option for people, says Walkinshaw. &ldquoThe industry doesn&rsquot believe in picosats. This is an attitude that we&rsquore overturning in a global way.  38 Eubha Akilade  Actor, 20  Why? She&rsquos a time-travelling hit with teenagers across the globe  Unless you&rsquore a tween, you probably haven&rsquot heard yet of Find Me In Paris, but, filling you in here, it&rsquos massive. It&rsquos the latest big Nickleodeon tween show, a time-travel drama about an international dance school, and it features a cast from all over the world, one of whom is 20-year-old Eubha Akilade from Glasgow.  On only her third acting job after she was spotted in an open call audition for CBBC show Eve, she is hitting the big time. Akilade recalls that following her audition, she found out within weeks that she would be off to Paris, and living for six months in an aparthotel with a cast of actors. Sounds like a party waiting to happen? &ldquoActually, no, she says. &ldquoThere&rsquos surprisingly little of that. We don&rsquot have time and have to keep ourselves in top form.  37 Gareth Williams  Entrepreneur, 49  Why? He had an idea in a pub &ndash which made billions  Ask any tech-oriented entrepreneur who their hero is and many will say Elon Musk. Ask that same question to an entrepreneur in Scotland and chances are, they&rsquoll say Gareth Williams, co-founder of Skyscanner.  He&rsquos the man who made a digital boom in Scotland seem possible &ndash and it all started with a drink in a pub between friends, and an idea generated because Williams was struggling to find cheap flights to the Swiss Alps.  Two years ago Skyscanner was sold to a Chinese company for &pound1.4 billion in 2016. But the the early days of Skyscanner weren&rsquot nearly so easy. &ldquoIt was two years, Williams has said, &ldquobefore we got our first revenue &ndash we earned &pound46 in one month. Yes, I miss those days but it&rsquos easy to forget the struggle of the startup days. There&rsquos a lot I don&rsquot miss.  36 Dr Liberty Vittert  Statistician, 29  Why? She uses maths to predict the future  Statistics, boring? Not when they&rsquore in in the hands of Dr Liberty Vittert, though even she says that at dinner parties she&rsquos prone to saying that she&rsquos a &ldquodata scientist studying fake news rather than statistician. Anyone who has watched her TEDx talk, How To Win The Lottery And Get Away With Murder will know, however, that there are many good reasons to love stats.  Vittert grew up in the US, and currently has a post at the University of Glasgow. Among her projects is one working with the cleft lip and palate charity Smile Train to map the human face to help children with facial deformities. She is also working on a &ldquofun TV show called Lies And Alcohol.  Remarkably, it turns out that, at school, Vittert wasn&rsquot good at mathematics. When she was 14 years old a maths teacher called her parents into school to say that, as she puts it, &ldquoI was too dumb to be there and was just simply not smart enough to understand basic math. &ldquoI have the most wonderful mother in the world who decided to get me a tutor and spent hours helping me. I just needed to learn maths in a dferent way. Sometimes, I wonder who the dumb one was in that whole scenario.  35 Kyle Ross  Barber, 28  Why? Because those beards are winning  When last year, Kyle Ross, MD of The Huntsman barbers in Aberdeen, went to Nurnberg for the final of the International Barber&rsquos competition, he won the trophy for best UK barber.  As ambassador for Hanz de Fuko, he&rsquos also traveling the world and attending fashion weeks in London and Paris. But, actually, he doesn&rsquot class himself as a barber. He&rsquos more, he says, of a hairstylist. So, those Aberdonians heading to The Huntsman get the kind of attention that comes with that. He teaches them to maintain their style, or gives them one that suits their lestyle rather than what&rsquos on trend.  34 Donald MacLeod  Club owner and charity chair  Why? The maverick music man is all about the charity these days  One thing you can be sure of is that given the bands that have played at his venues &ndash Oasis, Queens Of The Stone Age, Pearl Jam &ndash music promoter and club supremo Donald MacLeod must have some cracking tales.  Not long after he started The Cathouse, in 1990, he has said, he gave up being in a band and became a music promoter because he realised what the people wanted was short-haired indie kids, not long-haired rockers like him. He still has that hair and stylish dress sense &ndash and the persistence almost makes it cool. but these days, as chair of Nordoff Robbins, the music therapy charity, he&rsquos more about the power of music. He once said, &ldquoI encourage all bands to put a bit back so why not to Nordoff Robbins, who use music to do good?  33 Judy Murray  Tennis coach, 59  Why? She showed us she was more than just Andy&rsquos mum  Murray is not just cool because she&rsquos mother to two outstanding tennis stars. She&rsquos cool because somewhere in her fties, after years of having been nagged at by the media, she seemed to blossom.  It started with that fabulous appearance on Strictly Come Dancing and then it just snowballed, till last year, there she was getting a spider tattoo and publishing her autobiography, Keeping The Score. That spider tattoo says it all. The arthropod was a reference to the one Robert the Bruce saw struggling in a cave and her belief in &ldquoperseverance and the rewards that come with endless effort.  Somehow she got through it all &ndash and is no longer just Andy and Jamie&rsquos mum, but a national treasure in her own right.  32 Mark Mackie  Director of Regular Music  Why? We&rsquore loving those Summer Nights at the Bandstand in Kelvingrove Park  The bands may be cool but it&rsquos Mark Mackie of Regular Music who brings them to us. Whether at Edinburgh Castle, Kelvingrove or Loch Lomond, he&rsquos been delivering to us some of the industry&rsquos biggest names.  In fact, he&rsquos been doing that since way back when he was a student at Glasgow University, where, strangely enough, he studied marine science and zoology. For Mackie wanted to follow in the footsteps of his idol Jacques Cousteau, until he became entertainments convenor of the Queen Margaret Union and got into bringing the best of bands into town. Marine science&rsquos loss, Scottish culture&rsquos gain.  31 Lynne Ramsay  Film-maker, 28  Why? She&rsquos a tough genius working in a hard industry  You&rsquove got to hand it to Lynne Ramsay. Last year, at the Cannes Film Festival, she got a standing ovation, as well as prizes for best screenplay and best actor, for a film that wasn&rsquot even finished.  The film, You Were Never Really Here, starring Joaquin Phoenix, arrived on the screen straight out of the sound-mix and the audience loved it. It was a comeback to quell all the doubters who thought that when she walked out of directing Jane Got A Gun, her career was over.  But, the really cool thing about Ramsay is she sticks to her guns, and true to her working-class Glasgow background is always direct.  &ldquoYou know, she said in an interview this year, &ldquoI grew up in a place where people appreciate it when you&rsquore very direct. I think that helps cut through a lot of bullshit with filming. Straight talking and going on your instincts was important when I grew up.  30 Kapka Kassabova  Author, 45  Why? She took us to the edge of Europe  Kapka Kassabova&rsquos Border: A Journey To The Edge Of Europe was a book that was hard to pigeon-hole. Was it a memoir? A travelogue? A meditation on history and a lost part of Europe?  One thing that the literary world could agree on last year was that the book &ndash which won the Saltire and other awards &ndash was a marvel. Kassabova lives in a cottage in rural Inverness-shire, but she grew up in Communist Bulgaria, and Border tells the story of her  visit to the border between Turkey, Bulgaria and Greece and the people she met there. She describes her books as &ldquogenre-bending hybrids of narrative non-fiction. Currently, she is writing another book and travelling to Macedonia and Albania to visit the world&rsquos oldest lakes. It will, she says, be a &ldquojourney into an ancestral landscape through my mother&rsquos family.  29 Danny MacAskill  Mountain biker, 32  Why? We never get bored of his bike tricks  &ldquoI finally made it to Graub&uumlnden, says Danny MacAskill in his most recent film as he poses on his bike on the top of the Swiss mountain, before catapulting off on one of his high-adrenalin rides. In the film, sponsored by Red Bull, it&rsquos still the same old Danny, only the mountains are higher, the budgets are bigger, and, well, it&rsquos hard for him ever to top the feeling that he gave us when he did his first street trials video back in 2009, or the romance he delivered when he cycled The Ridge.  But nevertheless, the boy from Dunvegan, Isle of Skye, still knows how to move us &ndash and he&rsquos always bringing us something new. He did so earlier this, in spite of a recent broken knee cap, when he performed in the Celtic Connections music and bike spectacular Bothy Culture And Beyond.  &ldquoI suppose when you first jump on your bike it&rsquos your first dose of freedom, he said in a recent film about his Kilimanjaro bike trip. &ldquoYou can constantly think of something new to challenge yourself and it&rsquos kind of like a game that you&rsquoll never get bored of.  28 Anna Meredith  Composer, 40  Why? She took the Edinburgh International Festival by storm  Bright, breezy and pleasantly down to earth isn&rsquot how you&rsquod imagine a composer of left field music to be &ndash this, after all, is the woman who wrote a concerto for beatboxer and orchestra, and another piece to be performed using &ldquobody percussion by a flash mob at the M6 services.  But the description fits Anna Meredith perfectly. A 10-year veteran of commissions for the BBC Proms and a winner of the Scottish Album Of The Year for Varmints, her debut record, the Scot&rsquos playful but intellectually rigorous compositions had already won her a legion of admirers before this year&rsquos Edinburgh Festival.  After it, she was the name on everyone&rsquos lips thanks to having had not one but three separate works performed in the capital, including an orchestrated  performance of Varmints as part of the uber-cool Light On The Shore series at the Leith Theatre.  27 Robbie Grfith  Freerunner, 17  Why? He delivers his parkour thrills Renton-style  &ldquoChoose le. Choose a sport. Choose an interest. These were the words which kicked off a viral video, a parkour remake of the classic Trainspotting scene, in which Coatbridge-lad, Grfith flipped and hurtled across Edinburgh, until it concluded with the alternative line, &ldquoChoose parkour.  The film, Grfith recalls, was triggered when his brother suggested that he should make a video to the Trainspotting track and his dad then suggested they should go one further and remake the scene. Grfith and a film-maker friend made it, uploaded it in March last year, and overnight became a sensation. Since then Grfith has travelled the world with parkour, competing, visiting friends, doing a six month tour of America with his sponsor, the Motus Projects, and yes making more videos.  26 Mhairi Black  SNP MP, 24  Why? She won&rsquot be told, on anything  One of the coolest things about Mhairi Black is the way that three years at Westminster doesn&rsquot seem to have changed her very much at all. Yes, she&rsquos got a little older &ndash she went in at just 20 years old &ndash but she hasn&rsquot got any quieter or less determined. When, as she has said, Alex Salmond suggested to her that she should have a bit of a makeover and some new clothes, she ignored the advice. When online haters took her to pieces she shrugged them off, and then fought back &ndash with a powerful speech earlier this year describing some of the misogynistic and homophobic comments she received.  Mhairi Black is who she is &ndash gay, smart, passionate, angry, socialist &ndash and she&rsquos not changing any of that for anyone. She even still maintains her disregard for the institution which she is part of and, just last month, reiterated her feelings. &ldquoIt does not serve us, she said, &ldquoand in actual fact I would go so far as to say it&rsquos not even a parliament it&rsquos a club that masquerades itself.  25 Katie Archibald  Cyclist, 24  Why? She&rsquos got style and medals  Katie Archibald is nothing  not colourful. Her hair has been just about every hue under the sun. Her left arm is tattooed by drawings from The Thinker of Tender Thoughts by the poet Shel Silverstein. On her right are the Olympic rings. Her love of motorbikes saw her crash at 70mph on a Cheshire lane in the run up to the Rio Olympics.  But in between all this colour and extracurricular drama, there are the races and that really cool thing she does which is to win medals &ndash three at this year&rsquos Commonwealth Games and she has her eyes on three, too, at the next Olympics in Tokyo 2020.  24 Bigg Taj  Beatboxer, 35  Why? His mouth is a drum machine  As a kid Bigg Taj started doing beatbox long before he knew what those sounds he was making were. Then, he says, &ldquowhen I heard guys like Killa Kela, Rahzel and Scratch, I realised what it is and decided to pursue it. It&rsquos been my passion for well over a decade, creating music with my mouth and pushing the boundaries of my vocals.  Now Scotland&rsquos premier beatboxer, Bigg Taj, a Sikh of Indian heritage, has performed with his idols, supporting Method Man and Redman. But Bigg Taj isn&rsquot just about the performance &ndash he also runs a Youtube channel with beatbox tutorials and has been doing youth work for years. The workshops, he says, are about the creative writing and beatboxing, but they&rsquore also about giving young people a space to talk. Among these, he says, is one in Polmont prison with rap emcee Spee Six Nine.  23 Claire Cunningham  Dancer, 41  Why? She alters the way we look at bodies, able or disabled  Dancer and choreographer Claire Cunningham&rsquos extraordinary shows have always challenged how people feel about disability. When she dances on crutches &ndash which she has used to walk since the age of fourteen &ndash they become marvellous, magical and sometimes humorous extensions of herself. Her shows ask big questions. Guide Gods, for instance, looked at religious attitudes towards the disabled. Give Me a Reason to Live was based on the depiction of disability in the work of the painter Hieronymus Bosch. It was, she said, a live memorial to the disabled victims of the Nazi euthanasia program.  Cunningham was born with osteoporosis and arthrogryposis, but didn&rsquot view herself as disabled until she went to university. Only later, when she came in contact with the choreographer Jess Curtis, did she realise that she might be able to dance, and that she had her own very special set of tools, her crutches.  Her most recent work, The Way You Look  Tonight is a collaboration with Curtis.  22 Richard Madden  Actor, 32  Why? Two words. The Bodyguard.  Richard Madden, without a doubt, is having his own special cool moment right now. It&rsquos happening for him. The Bodyguard, in which he stars as Sergeant David Budd, is, according to the BBC, their &ldquodrama of the decade.  At the bookies, the odds on him being the next Bond just got slashed to 10/1. He&rsquos having to worry about being objectied and being seen as a hunk.  You can&rsquot open a newspaper without coming across some article about who he is dating &ndash actor Ellie Bamber &ndash or what his latest movements have been. But, one of the coolest things about the Renfrewshire born actor, whose biggest role, previous to this was Robb Stark in Game Of Thrones, is that he clearly acknowledges he hasn&rsquot always been cool. In one interview he confessed that  he weren&rsquot acting he&rsquod be a &ldquoshy, fat kid living in Scotland with no girlfriend.  21 Shirley Manson  Singer, 52  Why? She&rsquos not going to be owned by anyone  &ldquoI actually feel that this is the most glorious part of my career, Manson said earlier this year. And it is, on many levels &ndash not just because her band, Garbage, have stuck together for over twenty years, but because she&rsquos being more outspoken, almost, now more than ever and she is showing younger artists the way to go. She has spoken out on #MeToo.  Earlier this year she wrote a moving op-ed in the New York Times about her experience of self harm. &ldquoI didn&rsquot know I was a cutter until the first time I chose to cut, she wrote. &ldquoI didn&rsquot even know it was a &lsquothing.&rsquo..  Last month she had a go at the mainstream music industry, calling it &ldquoexploitative. Along with Chvrches frontwoman, Lauren Mayberry, she is set to deliver the keynote speech at the annual South by Southwest conference next year &ndash and you can bet it will be fizzing with feminism.  But above all, it&rsquos glorious because of the raw power she still has a performer. Garbage performed at the Barrowlands earlier this month, and Peter Ross, reviewing the gig for The Times observed, &ldquoShe was amped, vamped, pumped veins made a river delta on her temples.

title: theresa-may-admits-to-getting-irritated-by-leadership-talk
story: The Prime Minister insisted she was focused on the country's future rather than her own, in a BBC interview to mark the six-month countdown to Brexit.  Mrs May criticised Mr Johnson for using "completely inappropriate" language when he described her Brexit strategy as putting the UK in a "suicide vest".  Around 50 Brexiteers met to war-game ways to oust the PM last Tuesday evening and Mr Johnson is widely-expected to vie to replace Mrs May.  Asked  she would reassure the Conservative Party she was not determined to go on and on, the PM told BBC Panorama's Inside No 10: Deal or No Deal?: "I get a little bit irritated but this debate is not about my future, this debate is about the future of the people of the UK and the future of the United Kingdom.  "That's what I'm focused on and that's what we should all be focused on.  "It's ensuring that we get that good deal from the European Union which is good for people in the UK, wherever they live in the UK, that's what's important for us ... It's the future of people in the UK that matters."  Mr Johnson faced a Tory backlash after comparing Mrs May's Brexit plan to a "suicide vest" and his former communications director, Guto Harri, said on Saturday that his ex-boss was "digging his political grave".  Mrs May said the former Foreign Secretary's comments were "not right".  She went on: "I have to say that that choice of language is completely inappropriate.  "I was Home Secretary for six years and, as Prime Minister for two years now using language like that was not right and it's not language I would have used."  The PM was once described as "bloody dficult woman" by former Cabinet minister Ken Clarke, and later claimed the description as a badge of honour.  She told the programme that person was "still there" but there was a &ldquodference between those who think you can only be bloody dficult in public and those who think actually you bide your time, and you're bloody dficult when the time is right and when it really matters."

title: a-good-week-for-the-eu-with-its-stance-on-hungary
story: Prime Minister Victor Orb&aacuten of the ruling Hungarian Fidesz party came to Strasbourg to debate the criticisms in a resolution drawn up by Dutch MEP and my group colleague Judith Sargentini. If anyone needs a refresher it is worth remembering this is a man who has called migrants poison, referred to &lsquomuslim invaders&rsquo and peddled anti-Semitic myths about George Soros. His government, democratically elected it has to be said, has forcibly retired judges, banned international NGOs from working in Hungary, built a fence to keep out refugees and lots more besides.  As one academic succinctly put it this week &ldquothe EU is like a club with a strong bouncer, but little security once you&rsquore inside the venue. The present Hungarian government has not been abiding by the values that make up the EU, and the EU, slowly, had got round to acting. The Parliament, for the first time ever, was to debate the triggering of Article 7 proceedings, effectively putting Hungary in a sin bin cutting funding, limiting voting rights and other measures until it plays by the rules.  On the day he simply fell back on tired rhetoric asserting that the report &ldquoinsults the honour of the Hungarian nation whilst feeding a victim complex that the Parliament had already made up its mind. He fell back on anti-immigration rhetoric repeatedly talking about migrants whilst ignoring all other criticisms proudly proclaiming that &ldquothe Hungarian people have decided not to be a nation of migrants.  Remember, Hungary signed up to the values of the EU when it joined and these values are part of the organisation. These include the rights of iniduals and the EU institutions must defend them where possible, particularly in the face of the threats we now face. Europe is a continent of migrants and  our history shows us anything it is that narrow minded anti-immigrant rhetoric always ends badly.  Unsurprisingly his speech fell flat. MEPs from the centre right EPP, the centre left S&ampD, the liberal ALDE and Green groups all stood one by one to condemn his government&rsquos actions and at the end of the day with 448 votes in favour the European Parliament voted to recommend the initiation of Article 7 proceedings. This is a real strong sign that EU values must be respected and could result in Hungary being stripped of its right to vote in the Council of the European Union.  The details of the resolution that we approved are grim reading. The Budgetary Control Committee recommends deduction of EU funding to Hungary over concerns that much of it ends up in the pockets of his cronies the Culture Committee condemns attacks on academic freedom the Constitutional Affairs Committee condemns infringement of judicial independence the Committee on Women&rsquos Rights condemns reversals on gender equality.  This week&rsquos debate got to the heart of what the EU is for. To what extent should the sovereign EU states be able to pick and choose from the common rules they all voluntarily signed up to? To what extent should the rest of us be able to call them on it? Can solidarity be imposed?  None of these have simple answer, and in the EU everything is connected to everything else, that&rsquos the point. Recently, in Greece a profligate series of Greek governments tipped their economy into chaos, and it was only EU support that avoided a worse disaster. But could, should, the EU have been gentler with the Greek people themselves? I would say yes, but then, why should my taxpayers in Scotland pay for irresponsible profligacy at the other end of the continent?  Catalonia too has shown that the EU is ultimately a club of member states and there is work to do. There&rsquos a democratic discussion that needs to be promoted between Barcelona and Madrid and the EU has not stepped up, though I hope it may yet. At least on Hungary, this week the Parliament has stood up for democracy and the rule of law.  However, in the face of this overwhelming display of what the EU can be, there were still 197 members of our European Parliament that opposed taking action against Mr Orb&aacuten. My greatest shock comes not from UKIP and the Front National, you&rsquod expect it of them, but from the UK Conservatives who were the only governing right-wing party to support him.  They voted to support the policies and the man, in the face of everything he stands for. My most charitable explanation is that this shows the chronic weakness of the UK post-Brexit as its government desperately cuddles up to anyone who might provide some help irrespective of morals or long-term strategic cost. At its worst this is a sign that the Conservative party is shting hard to the right and anything goes.  I think it is the latter and increasingly I do not think you can describe the Conservatives as a centre-right party. The clues are in the company they keep. It was because of an ill thought out commitment to appease the right in David Cameron&rsquos 2005 leadership campaign that the party left the centre-right EPP group of the parliament and set up their own. Earlier this year they invited the anti-migrant Swedish-Democrats to join them. Yes, the party that was the focus of so much concern in last weekend&rsquos Swedish election are happy members of the same Group as Mrs May&rsquos Tories.  Unfortunately, the rhetoric of our Prime Ministers also fits with that of the hard right. David Cameron talked about &ldquoswarms of migrants. In the debate this week Mr Bay of the French Front National said that &ldquothe EU promotes multiculturalism, against out values. How is that so dferent from Mrs May&rsquos &ldquo you believe you are a citizen of the world, you are a citizen of nowhere?  I fear for the Tories and for what they may turn into. I fear for what that means for the rest of us  we&rsquore stuck in a brexit Britain run by them. Right now there is a fight going on in constituency branches across the UK. This is a fight for the soul of their party and I fear the old fashioned &lsquosmall c&rsquo liberal Conservatives are losing. There are still those fighting but they are increasingly cast out or in a minority. The MEPs Richard Ashworth and Julie Girling voted against Orb&aacuten but they have already felt the need to leave the Conservative group in the Parliament. Only one actual Tory MEP voted against Orb&aacuten and I want to end by praising Nosheena Mobarik, Conservative MEP for Scotland. She not only voted with us and her conscience, she defied what I&rsquod guess was a pretty tough London imposed group whip as well. I hope her colleagues across the UK will look to her action, ask themselves some hard questions and set about challenging those who are changing the Tory party into something they find unthinkable. Their silent acquiescence has implications for all of us.

title: scottish-high-streets-in-the-running-to-be-named-best-in-the-uk
story: The retail hotspots are all in the running to win a &pound15,000 prize as part of the Great British High Street Awards 2018.  The Scottish high streets shortlisted for the overall champion category include: Alness High Street, Ross and Cromarty A77 Pollokshaws/Kilmarnock Road corridor, Glasgow Turrf High Street, Aberdeenshire Kirriemuir High Street, Angus Kirkwall High Street, Orkney and Newport-on-Tay High Street, Fe.  Newport-on-Tay is also in the running for the rising star award, as well as Prestwick Main Street and Ayr High Street.  The categories will now be put to a public vote, which counts for 30 per cent of the final score, before being looked at by a judging panel.  High Streets Minister Jake Berry MP said: &ldquoCongratulations to all 38 high streets shortlisted for this year&rsquos Great British High Street Awards.  &ldquoThe awards celebrate the great work that is being done to revive, adapt and ersy the nation&rsquos high streets and the quality of entries this year has been outstanding.  &ldquoOver the next six weeks they have the chance to impress an expert judging panel as they also battle it out in a public vote for the title of Britain&rsquos best high street.  &ldquoThis is a great opportunity to show your support for all the hard work taking place on our high streets, so get voting.  The shortlist comes after recent research by credit card firm Visa, which sponsors the awards, showed signs of renewed confidence in the country&rsquos high streets despite a challenging retail environment.  The findings revealed that more than a third  of Scotland&rsquos independent high street retailers are optimistic about the future of their local high street, while almost four out of five  Scottish shoppers claim they would miss their local high street  it was no longer there.  Sundeep Kaur, head of UK &amp Ireland Merchant Services at Visa, said: &ldquoAt a time when the nation&rsquos high streets are transforming, this year&rsquos Great British High Street Awards shortlist contains some fantastic examples of high streets and merchants which are evolving and embracing change to attract visitors.  &ldquoIt is genuinely heartening to see so many businesses and communities that are harnessing their adaptability, resilience and creativity to offer the services and experiences that today&rsquos shoppers want.  Author and TV presenter Simon Reeve, who will act as a judge, added: &ldquoI&rsquove spent the last couple of months visiting independent high street retailers across the UK and I&rsquove been blown away by the passion and commitment shown by shopkeepers to keep their high streets alive, especially in this challenging climate.  &ldquoThe best examples are those that are listening closely to their customers and innovating to meet their demands. These are the shops and high streets that will stand the test of time.  A total of 38 high streets have been shortlisted for the 2018 awards, which are organised by the Ministry of Housing, Communities &amp Local Government.  The public and the judges will select an overall UK winner, as well as a winner from England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland for each of the two categories: the Champion and Rising Star awards.  The UK champion will receive a &pound10,000 grant for a local community project, while each of the inidual country winners will receive &pound5000 towards a street party.  The Rising Star winners will each receive &pound5000 towards a local community project.  The results will be revealed at an awards ceremony in London on November 15.  Anyone looking to vote in the awards can do so at www.thegreatbritishhighstreet.  Previous winners of the best high street award include Blackburn in 2016, Bishy Road in York in 2015, and Norwich Lanes in Norfolk in 2014.  The awards did not take place last year.

title: sketch-perhaps-its-time-for-those-too-nice-lib-dems-to-get-nasty
story: The question arises as it seems dferent Liberal Democrats have dferent takes on just how being in bed, politically speaking of course, with the likes of David Cameron and George Osborne during those oh-so-stable Coalition years really was.
